message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has multiple symptoms and findings that suggest Gardner syndrome, including bloody stools, colon polyps, bony swellings, subcutaneous nodules, and pigmented lesions on the retina. Cronkhite-Canada syndrome is characterized by a distinct set of symptoms and findings that are not present in this case, while Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and Cowden syndrome have some similar features but do not present with the same combination of symptoms and findings as Gardner syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has multiple symptoms and physical findings that suggest Gardner syndrome, including bloody stools, colonic polyps, bony swellings, subcutaneous nodules, and darkly pigmented lesions on the retina. Cronkhite-Canada syndrome presents with nail changes and hair loss. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome has mucocutaneous pigmentation and gastrointestinal polyps, but not the other symptoms present in this patient. Cowden syndrome presents with mucocutaneous lesions, but not the other symptoms present in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of multiple colonic polyps and a family history of colon cancer suggest Gardner syndrome. The painless bony swellings, subcutaneous nodules with central black pores, and oval darkly pigmented lesions on the retina are also characteristic of Gardner syndrome. Cronkhite-Canada syndrome and Peutz-Jeghers syndrome both present with gastrointestinal symptoms, but do not have the bony or ophthalmologic findings seen in Gardner syndrome. Cowden syndrome is associated with multiple hamartomas and an increased risk of breast and thyroid cancer, but does not typically present with colonic polyps.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with Gardner syndrome, which includes multiple colonic polyps, osteomas (bony swellings), subcutaneous nodules with central black pores, and pigmented lesions on the retina. Cronkhite-Canada syndrome and Peutz-Jeghers syndrome also present with mucocutaneous polyps, but they do not have the osteomas and pigmented lesions seen in this patient. Cowden syndrome presents with multiple hamartomas (benign tumors) but not colonic polyps.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Gardner syndrome, which is characterized by multiple colonic polyps, osteomas, and soft tissue tumors. The presence of skin lesions and family history make Peutz-Jeghers syndrome another possibility, but the absence of mucocutaneous pigmentation makes it less likely. Cronkhite-Canada syndrome involves nail changes and alopecia, which are not present in this case. Cowden syndrome involves multiple hamartomas, not polyps.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, Gardner syndrome is characterized by multiple osteomas, cutaneous cysts, and colonic polyps. The bony swellings, subcutaneous nodules, and darkly pigmented lesions on the retina all point towards this diagnosis. Cronkhite-Canada syndrome does not have osteomas, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome only has a few hamartomatous polyps, and Cowden syndrome does not have colonic polyps.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The non-bloody diarrhea, family history of colon cancer, and the presence of multiple colonic polyps suggest Gardner syndrome. The painless bony swellings are known as osteomas and the presence of multiple subcutaneous nodules with central black pores is known as epidermoid cysts, which are both commonly seen in Gardner syndrome. Cronkhite-Canada syndrome is characterized by gastrointestinal polyps, hair loss, and skin pigmentation changes. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by gastrointestinal polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. Cowden syndrome is characterized by multiple hamartomas and an increased risk of breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, Gardner syndrome is most likely based on the patient’s symptoms. Gardner syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease characterized by colonic polyposis, osteomas, and soft tissue tumors. The patient’s history of bloody stools and polyps in colonoscopy are consistent with colonic polyposis, and the presence of osteomas and subcutaneous nodules suggests Gardner syndrome. The other options may have some of the individual symptoms but not as many as Gardner syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has multiple clinical features of Gardner syndrome, including bloody stools, multiple colonic polyps, and bony swellings. Other syndromes may also have colonic polyps, but only Gardner syndrome has bony swellings and subcutaneous nodules.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of small, painless bony swellings on the mandible, forehead, and right shin, and multiple non-tender, subcutaneous nodules with central black pores over the trunk and face suggests Gardner syndrome. The presence of approximately 150 colonic polyps seen on colonoscopy also supports this diagnosis. Cronkhite-Canada syndrome is characterized by gastrointestinal polyps, skin hyperpigmentation, and nail changes. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by gastrointestinal polyposis and mucocutaneous pigmentation. Cowden syndrome is characterized by multiple hamartomas and an increased risk of breast, thyroid, and other cancers.
